item.title: Niche CS Games
item.description: This is a list of cool games related to computer science that you might not know about. Incredible proof machine Free to play: incredible.pm/ A game about proving things using intuitionistic logic.

item.title: List of Knots
item.description: This is a list of simple knots, organized by use case. Meant as a reference for when you need a knot for something. Complicated rigging systems can easily be created by using multiple of these knots together.

item.title: Index.html
item.description: Hi, I’m Alex! Known online as “umnikos”. I like math, programming, and everything in-between. What is this place? This is my “blog” where I’ve decided to write things.

item.title: "Do Not Find the Fox" Game Variant
item.description: There’s been a “game” going semi-viral recently called “Do Not Find the Fox”. It’s pretty simple: You randomly select and place letter tiles, in order, and if you place all of them without ever spelling “fox” in any direction, you win.

item.title: Posts
item.description: These are the items that do not get significant edits after publication.

item.title: Hamiltonian Cycle Problem
item.description: Problem: Prove that finding a hamiltonian cycle in a graph (a cycle that visits every vertex exactly once) is NP-hard. This is a well-studied problem with numerous different proofs.

item.title: Quartz
item.description: Quartz is a static site generator, designed for digital gardening in an increasingly dead internet. I am just using it as the easiest (and laziest) tool out there for making a blog.

item.title: Browser Tab Notes
item.description: Lots of browser extensions[1][2] allow you to take notes inside of a new tab, but most of them store said notes inside local storage. This means that if you open multiple new tabs, all of them will have the same notes inside.
